text: Financial expert Suze Orman advises retirees to have at least 3 to 5 years of cash available to cover living expenses in case of a market downturn. This cash reserve acts as a safety net, allowing retirees to avoid selling investments at a loss during a market slump. Orman recommends creating a cash reserve by selling underperforming assets or taking small amounts from well-performing investments. Having 3 to 5 years of cash reserves can help protect against market unpredictability and allow investments to recover without being prematurely liquidated.
